    Introduction Simple example Implementation Dynamics equations

Dynamics equations

2024-04-18

Source: vignettes/equations.Rmd
equations.Rmd

While salmonMSE reports state variables by year, the model is configured to model a population by successive generations. Thus, the dynamics equations are currently organized by life stage.

As model development continues, the dynamics can be stated by stock and year.

Definitions

Definition of variable names and the corresponding slots in either the input (SOM) or output (SMSE) objects in salmonMSE.

Name Definition Type Class Slot
\(\textrm{NOS}\) Natural origin spawners Natural production SMSE NOS
\(\textrm{HOS}\) Hatchery origin spawners Hatchery SMSE HOS
\(\textrm{HOS}_\textrm{eff}\) Effective number of HOS, spawning output discounted by \(\gamma\) Hatchery SMSE HOSeff
\(C_\textrm{smolt}\) Carrying capacity of smolts (stock-recruit parameter) Habitat SOM capacity_smolt
\(P_\textrm{smolt}\) Maximum rate of recruitment of smolts (stock-recruit parameter) Habitat SOM prod_smolt
\(u^\textrm{PT}\) Pre-terminal fishery harvest rate Harvest SOM u_preterminal
\(u^\textrm{T}\) Terminal fishery harvest rate Harvest SOM u_terminal
\(m\) Mark rate of hatchery fish Harvest SOM m
\(\delta\) Mortality from catch and release (proportion) Harvest SOM release_mort
\(\textrm{Fec}\) Fecundity of spawners (eggs per female) Natural production SOM fec
\(\textrm{Fec}^\textrm{brood}\) Fecundity of broodtake (eggs per female) Natural production SOM fec_brood
\(p^\textrm{female}\) Proportion of female spawners in broodtake and spawners Natural production + Hatchery SOM p_female
\(\textrm{SAR}\) Smolt-to-adult recruit survival Natural production + Hatchery SOM SAR
\(\textrm{NOB}\) Natural origin broodtake Hatchery SMSE NOB
\(\textrm{HOB}\) Hatchery origin broodtake Hatchery SMSE HOB
\(s_\textrm{yearling}\) Survival of hatchery eggs to yearling life stage Hatchery SOM s_egg_smolt
\(s_\textrm{subyearling}\) Survival of hatchery eggs to subyearling life stage Hatchery SOM s_egg_subyearling
\(p_\textrm{yearling}\) Proportion of hatchery releases as yearling (vs. subyearling) Hatchery Internal state variable -
\(s_\textrm{prespawn}\) Survival of adult broodtake in hatchery Hatchery SOM s_prespawn
\(n_\textrm{yearling}\) Target number of hatchery releases as yearlings Hatchery SOM n_yearling
\(n_\textrm{subyearling}\) Target number of hatchery releases as subyearlings Hatchery SOM n_subyearling
\(p_\textrm{NOB}\) Proportion of the total broodtake of natural origin (vs. hatchery origin) Hatchery Internal state variable -
\(p_\textrm{HOB}\) Proportion of the total broodtake of hatchery origin (vs. natural origin) Hatchery Internal state variable -
\(p^\textrm{NOB}_\textrm{max}\) Maximum proportion of the natural origin broodtake from the escapement, i.e., NOB/NOS ratio Hatchery SOM pmax_NOB
\(\textrm{NOR}\) Natural origin return Natural production SMSE Return_NOS
\(\textrm{HOR}\) Hachery origin return Hatchery SMSE Return_HOS
\(p^\textrm{hatchery}\) Proportion of hatchery origin escapement to hatchery, available for broodtake Hatchery SOM phatchery
\(p^\textrm{HOS}_\textrm{removal}\) Proportion of hatchery origin escapement removed from spawning grounds, not available for broodtake Hatchery SOM premove_HOS
\(\gamma\) Reduced reproductive success of HOS (relative to NOS) Hatchery SOM gamma
\(\bar{z}\) Mean phenotypic value of cohort in natural and hatchery environments Fitness Internal state variable -
\(\theta\) Optimal phenotypic value for natural and hatchery environments Fitness SOM theta
\(\sigma^2\) Variance of phenotypic traits in population Fitness SOM fitness_variance
\(\Omega\) Selection strength: fitness variance relative to phenotypic variance Fitness SOM selection_strength
\(h^2\) Heritability of phenotypic traits Fitness SOM heritability
\(\bar{W}\) Population fitness in the natural or hatchery environment Fitness SMSE fitness
\(\ell_i\) Relative fitness loss at the i-th life stage (egg, fry, smolt) Fitness SOM rel_loss
\(\textrm{PNI}\) Proportionate natural influence Fitness SMSE PNI
\(m\) Mark rate of hatchery fish (affects fishery retention of hatchery fish relative to natural fish) Harvest SOM m
\(p_\textrm{NOS}\) Proportion of natural origin spawners (vs. effective HOS) Population dynamics Internal state variable -
\(p_\textrm{HOSeff}\) Proportion of effective hatchery origin spawners (vs. NOS) Population dynamics SMSE NOS, HOS_effective
\(p_\textrm{HOScensus}\) Proportion of hatchery origin spawners (vs. NOS) Population dynamics SMSE NOS, HOS

Natural production

First, we consider natural production in the absence of fitness effects from the hatchery and habitat improvement.

Fry

From the spawners (NOS and HOS) of generation \(g-1\), the corresponding fry production for generation \(g\) is calculated as:

\[\begin{align} \textrm{Fry}^\textrm{NOS}_g &= \textrm{NOS}_{g-1} \times p^\textrm{female} \times \textrm{Fec}\\ \textrm{Fry}^\textrm{HOS}_g &= \gamma \times \textrm{HOS}_{\textrm{eff}g-1} \times p^\textrm{female} \times \textrm{Fec} \end{align}\]

where \(\textrm{HOS}_{\textrm{eff},g-1} = \gamma \times \textrm{HOS}_{g-1}\).

Smolts

Survival to the smolt stage is density-dependent throught the Beverton-Holt stock-recruit relationship. Smolt production is

\[\begin{align} \textrm{Smolt}^\textrm{NOS}_g &= \frac{P_\textrm{smolt} \times \textrm{Fry}^\textrm{NOS}_g}{1 + (\textrm{Fry}^\textrm{NOS}_g + \textrm{Fry}^\textrm{HOS}_g) \frac{P_\textrm{smolt}}{C_\textrm{smolt}}}\\ \textrm{Smolt}^\textrm{HOS}_g &= \frac{P_\textrm{smolt} \times \textrm{Fry}^\textrm{HOS}_g}{1 + (\textrm{Fry}^\textrm{NOS}_g + \textrm{Fry}^\textrm{HOS}_g) \frac{P_\textrm{smolt}}{C_\textrm{smolt}}} \end{align}\]

Hatchery production

Broodtake

The target total broodtake is calculated as

\[ \textrm{Broodtake} = \dfrac{n^\textrm{yearling}}{s^\textrm{prespawn} p^\textrm{female} \textrm{Fec}^\textrm{brood} s^\textrm{yearling}} + \dfrac{n^\textrm{subyearling}}{s^\textrm{prespawn} p^\textrm{female} \textrm{Fec}^\textrm{brood} s^\textrm{subyearling}} \]

The natural broodtake is

\[ \textrm{NOB}_{g-1} = \textrm{max}(p^\textrm{NOB}_\textrm{target} \times \textrm{Broodtake}, p^\textrm{NOB}_\textrm{max} \times \textrm{NOR}^\textrm{escapement}_{g-1}) \]

The hatchery broodtake is

\[ \textrm{HOB}_{g-1} = \textrm{min}(\textrm{Broodtake} - \textrm{NOB}_{g-1}, \textrm{HOR}^\textrm{escapement}_{g-1} \times p^\textrm{hatchery}) \]

Smolt releases

From the total broodtake \(\textrm{NOB}_{g-1}\) and \(\textrm{HOB}_{g-1}\), the smolt releases is calculated as

\[ \textrm{Smolt}^\textrm{Rel}_g = (\textrm{NOB}_{g-1} + \gamma \times \textrm{HOB}_{g-1}) s^\textrm{prespawn}p^\textrm{female} \textrm{Fec}^\textrm{brood}s^\textrm{hatchery} \]

where the average survival of all hatchery fish from the egg to yearling stage is

\(s^\textrm{hatchery} = s^\textrm{subyearling} (1 - p^\textrm{yearling}) + s^\textrm{yearling} p^\textrm{yearling}\) and \(p^\textrm{yearling} = n^\textrm{yearling}/(n^\textrm{subyearling} + n^\textrm{yearling})\).

Pre-terminal fishery

Harvest \(u^\textrm{PT}\) in the pre-terminal (\(\textrm{PT}\)) fishery, assuming no mark-selective fishing, occurs simultaneously along with marine survival (\(\textrm{SAR}\), constant base term). Pre-terminal fishery catch of immature NOS of generation \(g\) is calculated as

\[ \textrm{Catch}^\textrm{NOS,PT}_g = \dfrac{F^\textrm{PT,NOS}_g}{Z^\textrm{PT,NOS}_g}(1 - \exp(-Z^\textrm{PT}_g))[\textrm{Smolt}^\textrm{HOS}_g + \textrm{Smolt}^\textrm{NOS}_g] \]

where \(F^\textrm{PT}_g\) is solved such that \(u^\textrm{PT} = \frac{F^\textrm{PT,NOS}_g}{Z^\textrm{PT,NOS}_g}(1 - \exp(-Z^\textrm{PT,NOS}_g))\), \(Z^\textrm{PT,NOS}_g = F^\textrm{PT,NOS}_g + M^\textrm{SAR,NOS}_g\).

In the absence of fitness effects, \(M^\textrm{SAR,NOS}_g = -\log(\textrm{SAR}^\textrm{NOS})\).

Similarly, the pre-terminal fishery catch of immature HOS in generation \(g\) is

\[ \textrm{Catch}^\textrm{HOS,PT}_g = \dfrac{F_g^\textrm{PT,HOS}}{Z^\textrm{PT,HOS}_g}(1 - \exp(-Z^\textrm{PT,HOS}_g))\textrm{Smolt}^\textrm{Rel}_g \]

and SAR can differ between natural origin and hatchery origin fish.

Recruitment

The recruitment is calculated as the survival of smolts after pre-terminal harvest and marine survival:

\[\begin{align} \textrm{NOR}_g &= \exp(-Z^\textrm{PT,NOS})[\textrm{Smolt}^\textrm{HOS}_g + \textrm{Smolt}^\textrm{NOS}_g]\\ \textrm{HOR}_g &= \exp(-Z^\textrm{PT,HOS})\textrm{Smolt}^\textrm{Rel}_g \end{align}\]

Terminal fishery

Assuming no mark-selective fishing, the retained catch of the terminal (\(\textrm{T}\)) fishery is calculated from the harvest rate \(u\):

\[\begin{align} \textrm{Catch}^\textrm{NOS,T}_g &= u^\textrm{T} \textrm{NOR}_g\\ \textrm{Catch}^\textrm{HOS,T}_g &= u^\textrm{T} \textrm{HOR}_g \end{align}\]

Escapement

The escapement consists of the survivors of the terminal fishery:

\[\begin{align} \textrm{NOR}^\textrm{escapement}_g &= (1 - u^\textrm{T}) \textrm{NOR}_g\\ \textrm{HOR}^\textrm{escapement}_g &= (1 - u^\textrm{T}) \textrm{HOR}_g \end{align}\]

Spawners

The abundance of natural origin spawners consists of the escapement reduced by the broodtake.

The hatchery origin spawners is the escapement, reduced by the proportion \(p^\textrm{hatchery}\) returning to the hatchery, either by swim-in facilities or direct removal. A second removal term \(p^\textrm{HOS}_\textrm{removal}\) removes fish from the spawning grounds, these animals are not available for broodtake.

\[\begin{align} \textrm{NOS}_g &= \textrm{NOR}^\textrm{escapement}_g - \textrm{NOB}_g\\ \textrm{HOS}_g &= \textrm{NOR}^\textrm{escapement}_g (1 - p^\textrm{hatchery}) (1 - p^\textrm{HOS}_\textrm{removal}) \end{align}\]

Habitat improvement

Habitat improvement can improve either the productivity parameter, capacity parameter, or both.

Base terms \(P_\textrm{smolt}\) and \(C_\textrm{smolt}\) are used in the historical period of the model, e.g., for conditioning from data. In the projection, the stock recruit parameters \(P_\textrm{smolt}^\prime\) and \(C_\textrm{smolt}^\prime\) are updated with the improvement parameters, \(I_P\) or \(I_C\), as specified in the operating model:

\[\begin{align} P_\textrm{smolt}^\prime &= P_\textrm{smolt}I_P\\ C_\textrm{smolt}^\prime &= C_\textrm{smolt}I_C \end{align}\]

Fitness effects on survival

Reproductive success of hatchery fish has been observed to be lower than their natural counterparts, either through genetic or epigenetic causes, and is accounted for in the \(\gamma\) parameter (see review in Withler et al. 2018).

Through genetic and epigenetic factors, survival of hatchery juveniles in the hatchery environment selects for fish with a phenotype best adapted for that environment, and likewise for juveniles spawned in the natural environment. Since these traits are heritable, the fitness of the natural population can shift away from the optimum for the natural environment towards that of the hatchery environment on an evolutionary time scale, i.e., over a number of generations, when hatchery fish are allowed to spawn.

As described in Ford 2002 and derived in Lande 1976, the fitness loss function \(W\) for an individual with phenotypic trait value \(z\) in a given environment is

\[ W(z) = \exp\left(\dfrac{-(z-\theta)^2}{2\omega^2}\right) \]

where \(\theta\) is the optimum for that environment and \(\omega^2\) is the fitness variance.

If the phenotypic trait value \(z\) in the population is a random normal variable with mean \(\bar{z}\) and variance \(\sigma^2\), then the mean fitness of the population in generation \(g\) is \(\bar{W}(z) = \int W(z) f(z) dz\), where \(f(z)\) is the Gaussian probability density function. The solution is proportional to

\[ \bar{W}(z) \propto \exp\left(\dfrac{-(\bar{z}-\theta)^2}{2(\omega+\sigma)^2}\right) \]

We follow the mean fitness of generation \(g\) for the natural environment:

\[ \bar{W}^\textrm{natural}_g = \exp\left(\dfrac{-(\bar{z}^\textrm{natural}_g-\theta^\textrm{natural})^2}{2(\omega+\sigma)^2}\right) \]

The mean phenotype \(\bar{z}\) is calculated iteratively, where the change from generation \(g-1\) to \(g\) is

\[\begin{align} \Delta\bar{z} &= \bar{z}_g - \bar{z}_{g-1} = (\bar{z}^\prime_{g-1} - \bar{z}_{g-1})h^2\\ \bar{z}_g &= \bar{z}_{g-1} + (\bar{z}^\prime_{g-1} - \bar{z}_{g-1})h^2\\ \end{align}\]

where \(h^2\) is the heritability of \(z\) and \(\bar{z}^\prime_{g-1}\) is the trait value after applying the fitness function, defined as:

\[\begin{align} \bar{z}^\prime_{g-1} &= \dfrac{1}{\bar{W}_{g-1}}\int W_{g-1}(z)\times zf(z)dz\\ &= \left(\dfrac{\bar{z}_{g-1}\omega^2 + \theta \sigma^2}{\omega^2 + \sigma^2} - \bar{z}_{g-1}\right)h^2 \end{align}\]

With a hatchery program, the mean trait value of the progeny in the natural environment is a weighted average between the mean trait value of natural origin spawners in the natural environment (with optimum value \(\theta^\textrm{natural}\)) and that of hatchery origin spawners in the hatchery environment (with optimum value \(\theta^\textrm{hatchery}\)):

\[ \bar{z}^\textrm{natural}_g = (1 - p^\textrm{HOSeff}_{g-1}) \times \bar{z}^{\prime\textrm{natural}}_{g-1} + p^\textrm{HOSeff}_{g-1} \times \bar{z}^{\prime\textrm{hatchery}}_{g-1} \]

where \(p^\textrm{HOSeff} = \gamma\times\textrm{HOS}/(\textrm{NOS} + \gamma\times\textrm{HOS})\).

Similarly, the mean trait value in the hatchery environment \(\bar{z}^\textrm{hatchery}_g\) is a weighted average of the mean trait value of the natural origin broodtake in the natural environment and that of the hatchery origin broodtake in the hatchery environment:

\[ \bar{z}^\textrm{hatchery}_g = p^\textrm{NOB}_{g-1} \times \bar{z}^{\prime\textrm{natural}}_{g-1} + (1 - p^\textrm{NOB}_{g-1}) \times \bar{z}^{\prime\textrm{hatchery}}_{g-1} \]

where \(p^\textrm{NOB} = \textrm{NOB}/(\textrm{NOB} + \textrm{HOB})\).

The fitness variance \(\omega^2\) and phenotype variance \(\sigma^2\) are assumed constant between the two environments. The fitness variance is parameterized relative to the variance of the phenotype, i.e., \(\omega = \Omega \sigma\) where \(\Omega\) is the “selection strength”.

Fitness can reduce survival in the egg, fry, and smolt life stages:

\[\begin{align} \textrm{Fry}^\textrm{NOS}_g &= \textrm{NOS}_{g-1} \times p^\textrm{female} \times \textrm{Fec} \times (W^\textrm{nat.}_g)^{\ell_\textrm{egg}}\\ \textrm{Fry}^\textrm{HOS}_g &= \gamma \times \textrm{HOS}_{g-1} \times p^\textrm{female} \times \textrm{Fec} \times (W^\textrm{nat.}_g)^{\ell_\textrm{egg}} \end{align}\]

\[\begin{align} \textrm{Smolt}^\textrm{NOS}_g &= \frac{P_\textrm{smolt}^\prime (W^\textrm{nat.}_g)^{\ell_\textrm{fry}} \times \textrm{Fry}^\textrm{NOS}_g}{1 + (\textrm{Fry}^\textrm{NOS}_g + \textrm{Fry}^\textrm{HOS}_g) \frac{P_\textrm{smolt}^\prime}{C_\textrm{smolt}^\prime}}\\ \textrm{Smolt}^\textrm{HOS}_g &= \frac{P_\textrm{smolt}^\prime (W^\textrm{nat.}_g)^{\ell_\textrm{fry}} \times \textrm{Fry}^\textrm{HOS}_g}{1 + (\textrm{Fry}^\textrm{NOS}_g + \textrm{Fry}^\textrm{HOS}_g) \frac{P_\textrm{smolt}^\prime}{C_\textrm{smolt}^\prime}} \end{align}\]

\[ M^\textrm{SAR,NOS}_g = -\log(\textrm{SAR}^\textrm{NOS} \times (W^\textrm{nat.}_g)^{\ell_\textrm{smolt}}) \]

where \(\ell_i\) is the proportion of the fitness loss apportioned among the three life stages, \(\sum_i \ell_i = 1\).

PNI (proportionate natural influence) is an approximation of the rate of gene flow from the hatchery to the natural environment:

\[ \textrm{PNI}_g = \dfrac{p^{\textrm{NOB}}_g}{p^{\textrm{NOB}}_g + p^{\textrm{HOSeff}}_g} \]

Generally, a combination of minimizing hatchery releases, increasing natural broodtake, and reducing spawning of hatchery origin fish maintains high PNI (low rate of gene flow from the hatchery environment).

The proportion of wild salmon, natural origin fish whose parents were also natural spawners, is

\[ p^\textrm{WILD}_g = (1 - p^\textrm{HOScensus}_g) \times \dfrac{(1 - p^\textrm{HOScensus}_{g-1})^2} {(1 - p^\textrm{HOScensus}_{g-1})^2 + 2 \gamma \times p^\textrm{HOScensus}_{g-1}(1 - p^\textrm{HOScensus}_{g-1}) + \gamma^2 (p^\textrm{HOScensus}_{g-1})^2} \]

where \(p^\textrm{HOScensus} = \textrm{HOS}/(\textrm{HOS} + \textrm{NOS})\).

The first term is the proportion of natural spawners in the current generation \(g\).

The fraction in the second term discounts the proportion of the current generation to those whose parents were both natural spawners. Assuming non-assortative mating, the denominator in the second term is the composition of animals whose parents who are both natural origin, mixed origin (one parent in natural origin and the other is hatchery origin), and both hatchery origin.

Mark-selective fishing

If the mark rate \(m\) of hatchery fish greater than zero, then mark-selective fishing is implemented for both the pre-terminal and terminal fisheries. The mark rate is a proxy for retention and the harvest rate \(u^\textrm{harvest}\) corresponds to the ratio of the kept catch and abundance. The exploitation rate \(u^\textrm{exploit}\) is calculated from kept catch and dead releases. Exploitation rates differ between hatchery and natural origin fish because there is no retention of the latter.

Let the instantaneous fishing mortality for kept catch and released catch be

\[\begin{align} F^\textrm{kept} &= mE\\ F^\textrm{rel.} &= (1 - m)\delta E \end{align}\]

where \(\delta\) is the proportion of released fish that die.

\(E\) is an index of fishing effort that links together \(F^\textrm{kept}\) and \(F^\textrm{rel.}\). Intuitively, fishing effort can increase in a mark-selective fishery compared to non-selective fishery, e.g., if the mark rate is 20 percent, then the fishing effort could increase up to 500 percent higher than in a non-selective fishery in order to attain the kept quota or bag limit. Additional catch and release mortality then occurs for un-marked fish, according to \(\delta\).

In the pre-terminal (\(\textrm{PT}\)) fishery, \(E\) is solved to satisfy the following equation for hatchery fish:

\[ u^\textrm{harvest,HOS,PT} = \dfrac{F^\textrm{kept,PT}}{Z^\textrm{HOS,PT}}(1 - \exp(-Z^\textrm{HOS,PT})) \]

where \(Z^\textrm{HOS,PT} = F^\textrm{kept,PT} + F^\textrm{rel,PT} + M^\textrm{SAR,HOS} = mE^\textrm{PT} + (1 - m)\delta^\textrm{PT}E^\textrm{PT} + M^\textrm{SAR,HOS}\).

The corresponding exploitation rates are

\[\begin{align} u^\textrm{exploit,HOS,PT} &= \dfrac{F^\textrm{kept,PT} + F^\textrm{rel,PT}}{Z^\textrm{HOS,PT}}(1 - \exp(-Z^\textrm{HOS,PT}))\\ u^\textrm{exploit,NOS,PT} &= \dfrac{F^\textrm{rel,PT}}{Z^\textrm{NOS,PT}}(1 - \exp(-Z^\textrm{NOS,PT})) \end{align}\]

for natural and hatchery fish, respectively, and \(Z^\textrm{NOS,PT} = F^\textrm{rel,PT} + M^\textrm{SAR,NOS}\).

Similarly, the fishing effort of the terminal fishery satisfies the equation

\[ u^\textrm{harvest,HOS,T} = \dfrac{F^\textrm{kept,T}}{F^\textrm{kept,T} + F^\textrm{rel,T}}(1 - \exp(-[F^\textrm{kept,T} + F^\textrm{rel,T}])) \]

The corresponding exploitation rates are

\[\begin{align} u^\textrm{exploit,HOS,T} &= 1 - \exp(-[F^\textrm{kept,T} + F^\textrm{rel,T}])\\ u^\textrm{exploit,NOS,T} &= 1 - \exp(-F^\textrm{rel,T}) \end{align}\]
